articles.headline: Regulator Will Help Borrowers at IndyMac
articles.snippet: Troubled borrowers with mortgages from IndyMac will be able to seek lower-priced, fixed-rate loans under a plan unveiled by the regulatory agency that took over the failed thrift.
articles.abstract: Troubled borrowers with mortgages from IndyMac will be able to seek lower-priced, fixed-rate loans under a plan unveiled by the regulatory agency that took over the failed thrift.
articles.lead_paragraph: The regulator that seized IndyMac last month said Wednesday it would help thousands of the failed thrift institution’s cash-short borrowers repay their mortgages and stay in their homes, a model it hoped other banks and collection companies would adopt to stem a wave of new foreclosures in the nation’s weakened housing market.

articles.headline: Downsizing in Los Angeles: From Mansion to $47 Million Condo
articles.snippet: A New York-style luxury high-rise lifestyle is creeping into the wealthiest echelons of society in Los Angeles.
articles.abstract: A New York-style luxury high-rise lifestyle is creeping into the wealthiest echelons of society in Los Angeles.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Candy Spelling, widow of the television producer Aaron Spelling, is downsizing.

articles.headline: Report Rejects Medicare Boast of Paring Fraud
articles.snippet: Medicare officials’ 2006 statements that they had reduced the number of fraudulent and improper claims were misleading, a draft report says.
articles.abstract: Medicare officials’ 2006 statements that they had reduced the number of fraudulent and improper claims were misleading, a draft report says.
articles.lead_paragraph: Medicare’s top officials said in 2006 that they had reduced the number of fraudulent and improper claims paid by the agency, keeping billions of dollars out of the hands of people trying to game the system.

articles.headline: Prescriptions for Fannie and Freddie
articles.snippet: As policy makers work to ease the strain on Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, a consensus is emerging that the two companies will have to look substantially different in the long term.
articles.abstract: As policy makers work to ease the strain on Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, a consensus is emerging that the two companies will have to look substantially different in the long term.
articles.lead_paragraph: As policy makers work to ease the strain on the mortgage giants Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, a consensus is emerging that the two companies will have to look substantially different in the long term.

articles.headline: Rural Swath of Big State Tests Obama
articles.snippet: Once solidly Democratic, western Pennsylvania has become an uncertain political terrain and a target for John McCain.
articles.abstract: Once solidly Democratic, western Pennsylvania has become an uncertain political terrain and a target for John McCain.
articles.lead_paragraph: RACCOON TOWNSHIP, Pa. — Wander up a gravel road and ask George Timko about Barack Obama and John McCain and he wrinkles his nose. Neither of those guys strikes him as a prize.

articles.headline: Welcome, Freshmen. Have an iPod.
articles.snippet: Taking a step that professors may view as a bit counterproductive, some universities are doling out Apple iPhones and Internet-capable iPods to students.
articles.abstract: Taking a step that professors may view as a bit counterproductive, some universities are doling out Apple iPhones and Internet-capable iPods to students.
articles.lead_paragraph: Taking a step that professors may view as a bit counterproductive, some universities are doling out Apple iPhones and Internet-capable iPods to students.

articles.headline: From Snapshots, a 3-D View
articles.snippet: Photosynth, a sophisticated technology from Microsoft, turns a bunch of overlapping photos into a 3-D panorama.
articles.abstract: Photosynth, a sophisticated technology from Microsoft, turns a bunch of overlapping photos into a 3-D panorama.
articles.lead_paragraph: How do you describe a place? How do you express its essence to people who aren’t there?

articles.headline: Draft Accord With Iraq Sets Goal of 2011 Pullout
articles.snippet: U.S. combat troops will leave Iraqi cities by next June and the rest of the country by the end of 2011 if conditions stay relatively stable, officials said.
articles.abstract: U.S. combat troops will leave Iraqi cities by next June and the rest of the country by the end of 2011 if conditions stay relatively stable, officials said.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — The United States has agreed to remove combat troops from Iraqi cities by next June and from the rest of the country by the end of 2011 if conditions in Iraq remain relatively stable, according to Iraqi and American officials involved in negotiating a security accord governing American forces there.

articles.headline: 64 in Pakistan Die in Bombing at Arms Plant
articles.snippet: The attack was the worst by the Taliban since they began hitting government sites with suicide bombers more than 18 months ago.
articles.abstract: The attack was the worst by the Taliban since they began hitting government sites with suicide bombers more than 18 months ago.
articles.lead_paragraph: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  Two suicide bombers killed at least 64 people outside Pakistan’s biggest weapons factory complex on Thursday, in the deadliest attack by the Taliban since they began hitting Pakistani government sites with suicide bombers more than 18 months ago.
